4-2-24: Compliance With Provisions
4-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
The meanings of words used throughout this chapter shall be as set forth in the
"Glossary For Water And Wastewater Engineering" published by the American
Public Health Association.
The following definitions shall govern the construction of this chapter unless
otherwise apparent from the context:
CITY SEWER COLLECTION SYSTEM, CITY SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM AND PUBLIC SEWERS: Are
synonymous within this text, and are a collective term referring to the entire
piping system that transports domestic sewage within the city.
CLEAR WATER: Any water flow that is not domestic sewage and includes rainwater,
ground water, melted snow and ice, surface runoff, irrigation or sprinkler
discharge, and domestic car wash water.
OWNER: The person owning real or personal property that is, or proposes to be,
connected to the city sewer system.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or
group.
SERVICE CONNECTION: The point where the service line connects to city sewer
collection system.
SERVICE LINE: The sewer line running from the city sewer collection system to
the user's property.
USER: A person using the city sewer system and it shall be synonymous with
"owner". (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-2: ADMINISTRATION:
This chapter shall be administered as directed by the city council, and as
modified by the council from time to time.
   A.   All plumbing including wastewater and sewer within the exterior wall of
a structure is governed by the state of Idaho division of building safety using
the international plumbing code.
   B.   Service connections and the city sewer collection system are governed
by the city of Kellogg following South Fork Coeur d'Alene River sewer district
guidelines.
   C.   Septic systems are governed by the state of Idaho, Panhandle health
district.
   D.   All exterior sewer connections, including recreational vehicle
stations, are governed by the state of Idaho department of environmental
quality. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-3: REQUIRED CONNECTION:
   A.   All permanent residential building structures that include one or more
bedrooms, or a multiple use room that can be used as a bedroom (i.e., studio
apartment), shall contain at least one toilet and lavatory sink and connect
with the city sewer. All commercial building structures, that are occupied a
portion of the day, shall contain at least one toilet and lavatory sink and
connect with the city sewer.
   B.   Any commercial structure that has water service shall also be connected
to the sewer.
   C.   All plumbing fixtures and devices within the building structure that
generate wastewater shall be plumbed in accordance with the international
plumbing code and the applicable state permit shall be obtained by the owner.
(Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
   D.   All structures/properties that are connected to the city sewer must
have a line dedicated to the property. Shared/party lines connecting more than
one property to the service connection are not permitted.
   E.   If a structure does not comply with this required connection, the
superintendent of public works, or such officer as may be designated by the
city council, will present a notice of noncompliance. If within thirty (30)
days of the notice the owner or occupant does not comply with all the
requirements of this chapter and other regulations of the city council, the
inspector may employ a competent plumber to provide the connections at the
expense of the city, and upon the completion of the work the cost thereof shall
be certified to the city council, and upon confirmation thereof by city
council, an action may be commenced against the owner and occupant of the
premises for the recovery of the amount thereof together with costs.
   F.   Any property with a shared/party line must cease such shared/party use
upon any modification or upgrade to the shared service line. The requirement to
cease use applies regardless of the need for the modification. (Ord. 579, 10-
14-2015)
4-2-4: LIABILITY OF OWNER FOR CONNECTION:
When work is commenced to make a sewer connection, it shall be made by a
licensed person and be prosecuted with due diligence until completed. The owner
of the property for which the sewer connection is being made shall be liable
for all acts of negligence in making such connections. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-5: REFUSAL TO CONNECT A MISDEMEANOR:
Any owner or occupant of any premises within the city who refuses or neglects
to make sewer connections as provided by section
4-2-3 of this chapter within the time specified shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-6: PERMIT/APPLICATION/HOOKUP FEE:
   A.   No public sewer, or building sewer, shall be constructed, repaired or
modified until a permit/hookup fee has been obtained from the city of Kellogg
and a fee, set by resolution, is paid to that office.
   B.   If the applied for location is outside the bounds of the present sewer
collection system, a "will service" approval document must be issued by the
city and the South Fork Coeur d'Alene River sewer district before an
application process is begun.
   C.   Application for a permit shall contain all necessary information
requested by the city of Kellogg; and as required by other state or local
agencies.
   D.   Permits are issued at the time of building permit issuance and are
valid for one year from that date.
   E.   The city of Kellogg shall issue the permit only after collection of the
fee and receipt of all necessary information. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-7: COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAW:
All sewerage works construction shall comply with applicable standards as set
forth in the state of Idaho regulations and/or the international plumbing code.
(Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-8: INSPECTION; REPORT:
   A.   Inspection of the completed work prior to covering shall be made by the
superintendent of public works or other inspector duly authorized by the city
council.
   B.   The inspector will review the completed work, ascertain that materials,
workmanship, and construction details comply with standards and permit plans
and conditions. Upon a finding of satisfactory and compliant construction, the
inspector will sign the permit as complete providing adequate backfilling and
covering is evidenced.
   C.   Copies of the completed report are to be filed with the city of Kellogg
and with the South Fork Coeur d'Alene River sewer district. The original should
remain with the owner of the connected property. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-9: APPLICATIONS FOR PERMITS:
Applications for permits may only be made by owners of a property, or by their
duly authorized representatives. The owner is liable at all times for
compliance with this chapter and is subject to the penalties set forth in
section
4-2-13 of this chapter. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-10: MONTHLY SERVICE FEES:
There is established and assessed a sewer charge and fee for construction,
operation and maintenance of a sewer system against the owners of all premises
having, or required to have, connection with the sanitary sewage system of the
city upon the premises.
   A.   Each service connection discharging to the city sewerage system shall
pay a monthly fee as is determined and fixed by resolution of the council. The
city of Kellogg sewer fee shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the Kellogg
city hall.
   B.   In addition to the city fee, which is used for maintenance and
operation of the city sewerage system, each service connection shall pay an
additional fee to the South Fork Coeur d'Alene River sewer district to cover
maintenance and operation costs of the interceptor and treatment systems. Above
fees, set by resolution, may be modified by the responsible parties as needed
from time to time to match income to costs. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-11: PAYMENT OF FEES AND CHARGES:
   A.   All fees and charges are due and payable upon delivery of the notice of
charges.
   B.   Unpaid charges are delinquent twenty (20) days after delivery of
notice, and are subject to a basic penalty charge of ten percent (10%) of the
delinquent balance.
   C.   Extended delinquency is cause for disconnecting the service, with costs
for both disconnection and reconnection to be billed to the property.
Alternatively, delinquent charges may be assessed to the tax rolls. (Ord. 521,
10-11-2006)
4-2-12: APPEALS:
Aggrieved parties who feel unjustly treated under this chapter may file a
written appeal with the city council, within ninety (90) days of the cause of
the grievance, who shall set a specific time, date and place to hear such
complaint. The ruling of the city council, after such hearing, shall be final.
(Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-13: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   A.   Violations of any of the provisions of this chapter or failure to
comply with any of its requirements shall constitute a misdemeanor. Each day
such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense.
   B.   Any violations of this chapter may be punished by:
      1.   Immediate disconnection of the sewerage line;
      2.   A fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per day;
      3.   Both of the above. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-14: PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   No person shall connect any building or premises with the city sanitary
sewer system by a drain or connection nor permit a condition to exist, by which
clear water may be discharged into the city sanitary sewer system, and any
existing drain or connection by which such waters may be discharged into the
city sanitary sewer shall be disconnected, mechanically severed or altered.
   B.   By this chapter cesspools, septic tanks, private sewage treatment, or
any other drainage of domestic sewage other than to the city sewer collection
system is prohibited. Exception to this subsection may be granted upon
application approval by the Idaho department of environmental quality,
Panhandle health district, and third party engineering review. (Ord. 521, 10-
11-2006)
4-2-15: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
The sewer inspector of the city and/or his designees, upon identification, may
enter any building or premises supplied with public water service or public
sewer facilities for the purpose of inspecting and testing all plumbing,
together with all form of clear water drainage, to ascertain quantity, quality
and condition of sanitary and clear water sewerage facilities. (Ord. 521, 10-
11-2006)
4-2-16: CLEAR WATER CONNECTIONS; BUILDING FOUNDATION DRAINS:
All building foundation drains shall conform to the international plumbing
code. The drain shall terminate in a sump pit not less than twenty inches (20")
in diameter and twenty four inches (24") in depth. The sump crock shall project
a minimum of two inches (2") above the adjacent finished floor. An approved
ejector pump shall be maintained to be functional. The minimum size (ejector)
sump pump discharge and extensions thereto shall be one and one-fourth inches
(1 1/4"). The vertical discharge pipe shall be provided with a flexible joint
or sound deadening fitting. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-17: CLEAR WATER CONNECTIONS; SUMP PUMP SPECIFICATIONS:
All sump pump installations shall conform to the international plumbing code.
Sump pumps installed for the purpose of discharging clear waters from
foundation drains and ground infiltration, and where the building is not
serviced by a storm sewer, shall discharge into a drywell at least three feet
(3') outside the building exterior and of sufficient size to contain five (5)
minutes of discharge from the sump pump and percolate dry in an additional five
(5) minutes. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-18: VOLUME OF DISCHARGE LIMITED:
No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged into the city sanitary
sewer system by means of a drain or any connection the following total volume
of flow of normal domestic sewage:
   A.   Residential users: Total volume of flow not to exceed two hundred (200)
gallons per day per resident of the connected facility.
   B.   Business and commercial users: Total volume of flow not to exceed the
amount of metered water used per day. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-19: PROPERTY OWNER RESPONSIBILITY FOR MAINTENANCE:
It shall be the duty and responsibility of the property owner to install and
maintain the service line which provides service to the property up to the
point of connection to the city sewer collection system. The public sewer lines
are generally located within the public right of way (street or alley);
therefore the owner's responsibility includes the extension of the service line
into said right of way. The service line shall be permanent and watertight to
ensure that clear water including subsurface waters is not discharged into the
city sewer collection system. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-20: RESERVED:
(Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-21: PERMISSION REQUIRED TO OPEN MANHOLES:
No plumber, drain layer or other person shall open or uncover any manhole, air
inlet, flush tank, or other private connection with the public sewer, without
permission of the superintendent of public works or such other officer as may
be designated by the city council; nor shall any of such persons leave openings
to the sewer without ample protection against admission of dirt, rubbish or
other injurious matter. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-22: SEWER CONNECTIONS; PROCEDURE:
All connections with a public sewer or drain shall be made in a workmanlike
manner and conform to all state requirements and the international plumbing
code. The street must be opened and the earth deposited in a manner that will
occasion the least inconvenience to the public and provide for free passage
along the gutter. One-half (1/2) of the street must be left clear for the
passage of vehicles, and bridgeways must be provided on sidewalks for foot
passengers. In refilling the trench, the earth must be deposited in layers of
not more than six inches (6") in depth and well tamped to provide for
settlement. As soon as such drain or sewer is complete, the surface or the
street must be restored in as good condition as previous to the excavation and
all rubbish and surplus earth immediately removed. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-23: SEWER CONNECTIONS; NOTICE TO INSPECTOR:
Notice must be given the superintendent of public works by any person desiring
to make connection with any public sewer, previous to the time of making such
connection, when such work will be ready for inspection. The inspector of
plumbing shall inspect the same, and the connection shall be made in the manner
provided in the city's ordinances and to the satisfaction of the inspector
before the trench is filled. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
4-2-24: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
Failure to comply with the terms and provisions of this chapter shall be cause
for disconnecting the sewer service to the property and the costs of
disconnection and reconnection shall be billed to the property owner. After
sewer service to property has been disconnected, the sewer service shall not be
reconnected until a report as set forth in section
4-2-8 of this chapter has been completed. In addition, sewer service shall not
be reconnected until both the costs of disconnection and the anticipated costs
of reconnection are paid in full. The cost of disconnection, if sewer service
is not reconnected, shall be the responsibility of the property owner and if
the costs are not paid after being notified of the same, the costs shall be
assessed to the tax rolls. (Ord. 521, 10-11-2006)
CHAPTER 3
ELECTRICAL CODE
SECTION:
4-3-1: National Electrical Code Adopted
4-3-2: State License And Bond Required
4-3-3: Persons Making Own Installations
4-3-4: Permit Required; Application; Issuance
4-3-5: Inspection Requirements
4-3-6: Installation Of Meters And Outside Wiring
4-3-7: Specifications Of Service Wires
4-3-8: Certificate Of Inspection
4-3-9: Right To Enter Premises
4-3-10: Damage Not Assumed By City
4-3-11: Right Of Appeal
4-3-1: NATIONAL ELECTRICAL CODE ADOPTED:
All electric wiring, installation of electrical fixtures, apparatus or
electrical appliances, for furnishing light, heat or power, or other electrical
work introduced into or placed in or upon or in any way connected on any
building or structure within the limits of the city shall be in conformity with
the provisions set forth in the 1959 national electrical code, standard of the
National Board of Fire Underwriters for electrical wiring and apparatus as
recommended by the National Fire Protection Association including amendments
thereto, and as said code shall be amended, revised, compiled and published
from time to time, and all fittings and materials used in such construction or
installation shall be such as are sanctioned and approved in the latest list of
electrical fittings published by the National Board of Fire Underwriters. The
1959 national electrical code, standard of the National Board of Fire
Underwriters for electric wiring and apparatus as recommended by the National
Fire Protection Association and as the same shall be amended, revised, compiled
and published from time to time, is hereby adopted as the electrical code of
the city under and by virtue of authority granted by the provisions of section
50-2002, Idaho Code, three (3) copies of the above adopted code being on file
in the office of the city clerk and properly certified as the officially
adopted and certified electrical code of the city. (1961 Code)
4-3-2: STATE LICENSE AND BOND REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to carry on the
business of electric wiring without first having secured a state license so to
do and executing to the city a good and sufficient bond, signed by some surety
company authorized to transact business in the state of Idaho, in the penal sum
of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), running to the city, said bond to be
approved by the mayor and city council and conditioned by the saving of said
city harmless and free from all damages or costs by reason of his operation, or
his failure or neglect to properly perform any duties incumbent upon him, and
for faithful performance of the laws of the state of Idaho and the city. (1961
Code)
4-3-3: PERSONS MAKING OWN INSTALLATIONS:
If an owner wishes to do wiring in his own building, he may do so without a
state license, but he must first obtain a permit as required by this chapter.
The clerk may refuse to issue a permit to such person, if, in his estimation,
such person is not competent to install the electrical work to be done under
said permit applied for in accordance with the regulations of this chapter.
(1961 Code)
4-3-4: PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION; ISSUANCE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or install in any building any
wiring, apparatus or fixtures for the use of electric current for light, heat,
or power, or to make any alterations or changes in, or additions to any wiring,
apparatus or fixtures for such use, without first obtaining from the clerk a
written permit to do such work. Such permit shall state the kind of work to be
done and the amount, and shall cover only work so specified. The contractor,
person, firm or corporation shall submit a plan of wiring system to be followed
if deemed necessary by the clerk. Said permit shall also state the exact
location of the building where such work is to be done, and shall be valid only
for the location stated.
The fee should be charged for every permit issued under this chapter as
follows:
   Temporary Services: Five dollars ($5.00). A temporary service is a service

4-3-5: INSPECTION REQUIREMENTS:
It shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to inspect or cause to be
inspected any and all work for which permits have been issued within forty
eight (48) hours, Sunday and holidays excluded, after time of notice has been
received, in writing from the person, firm, contractor or corporation doing the
said work. The same will not be considered ready for inspection and covering
until all enclosed plumbing, steam heating, furnace work and gas fittings are
in place. Inspection shall, when necessary, be made two (2) or three (3) times
during the progress of installation; first when work is roughed in, and last,
when work is completed; and it shall be the duty of the electrical inspector or
person qualified and delegated by him, to indicate inspection of any work by a
tag or label, which shall specify the date and whether first or final
inspection has been made, and it shall be unlawful for any workman or other
person to lath or otherwise conceal any electrical wiring until such first
inspection tag has been placed.
   A.   Upon application for inspection of any wiring apparatus, or appliances
as hereinafter provided, the electrical inspector shall after inspection and
examination issue a certificate showing the results of such examinations and
require to be made the necessary corrections.
   B.   If the said electrical inspector shall find any part of any electric
light or power wiring apparatus or fixtures in or on any building in the city
to have been installed without a permit or not in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter or to be dangerous to life or property, the
electrical inspector shall have the right and power and it is hereby made his
duty to disconnect such defective wiring and place a seal upon it. He shall at
the same time give written notice of such disconnection to the owner or
occupant of the building. After such disconnected wiring, apparatus, fixtures
have been put in the condition required by this chapter, the seat or seals so
placed shall be removed by said electrical inspector. It shall be unlawful for
any person to use any current, through, or by means of such disconnected
wiring, apparatus or fixtures or to remove, break or deface any seal so placed.
The electrical inspector shall require all bathroom lights to be equipped with
a receptacle and switch which receptacle shall be so attached as to prevent any
person while standing in the bathtub to reach or touch the same. (1961 Code)
4-3-6: INSTALLATION OF METERS AND OUTSIDE WIRING:
   A.   Meters must be placed in a dry place, free from vibration and
accessible to the meter readers, testers and inspectors at all times. Under no
circumstances will meters be installed in bathroom, bedroom, clothes closets,
over doors, in stairways, attics or places likely to cause the visits to the
meters to be an annoyance to the occupants.
   B.   Meters shall be installed on the outside of buildings at a height of
not less than five feet (5'), or not more than six feet (6') from the ground.
In office buildings, apartment buildings, and commercial buildings of multiple
occupancy, meters may be mounted inside, providing a readily accessible place
is provided for meters and service equipment. Said meters and service equipment
shall be kept free and clear of all obstructions.
   C.   All buildings shall be provided with a main disconnecting switch and
all branch circuits shall be fused to match the wire size, in accordance with
the latest national code. All 240-volt circuits such as to ranges, dryers,
water heaters, cooking equipment, and motors above one horsepower shall have a
separate branch circuit to each appliance.
   D.   Wires carried on the outside of buildings, or attached thereto for
electric signs, outline or decorative and similar lighting, shall run in
approved metal conduit or approved armored cable. If the latter is used, it
shall be of a type having lead covering between the outer braid of the
conductors and the steel armor; all fittings such as outlets, fuses, switches
and similar devices, or on the outside of buildings and attached thereto, or,
otherwise exposed to moisture, shall be enclosed in approved weatherproof metal
boxes or cabinets. (1961 Code)
4-3-7: SPECIFICATIONS OF SERVICE WIRES:
   A.   All service wiring entering buildings shall be enclosed in conduit
which must be continuous from the service head to the inside of the cutout
cabinet.
   All switches must be of the enclosed safety type, with meter trim, and must
have branch fuse accessible to the consumer. Departure from this rule may be
made by special permission only. (1961 Code)
4-3-8: CERTIFICATE OF INSPECTION:
Upon the completion of the wiring in or on any building, it shall be the duty
of the corporation, copartnership, firm or individual doing the same to notify
the electrical inspector, who shall at once inspect the same and if approved by
him, shall issue a certificate of proper inspection which shall contain the
date of such inspection and an outline of the result; and it shall be unlawful
for any person to turn on or connect the current with such installation until
such certificate shall be issued; and it shall be unlawful to make any change,
alteration or extension in or to the wiring of any building after inspection
without first notifying said electrical inspector and procuring a permit
therefor. (1961 Code)
4-3-9: RIGHT TO ENTER PREMISES:
The electrical inspector shall have the right to enter any premises at all
reasonable hours for the purpose of inspecting the same. (1961 Code)
4-3-10: DAMAGE NOT ASSUMED BY CITY:
This chapter shall not be construed as to relieve from or lessen the
responsibility of any person owning, operating or installing any electrical
wires, appliances, apparatus, construction or equipment for damages to anyone
injured or damages either in person or property by any defect therein; nor
shall the city or any agent thereof be held as assuming such liability by
reason of inspection authorized herein or certificate of inspection issued.
(1961 Code)
4-3-11: RIGHT OF APPEAL:
Any applicant denied a permit under this chapter shall have the right to appeal
within ten (10) days to a board comprised of the city clerk, building
inspector, electrical inspector and plumbing inspector, by filing with the city
clerk written objections to the ruling and such board shall after due notice
hold a hearing and sustain said ruling or order the issuance of said permit.
(1961 Code)
CHAPTER 4
MOVING OF BUILDINGS
SECTION:
4-4-1: Permit Required
4-4-2: Sufficient Bond Or Liability Insurance Filed
4-4-3: File Continuous Bond
4-4-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to move any house,
building or other structure of any kind or nature upon, over, along or across
any of the streets or alleys in the city without first obtaining from the clerk
of said city a permit therefor, which said permit shall state the name of the
owner of said house, building or other structure, the name of the person to
whom the said permit is granted, the place from which and the plane to which it
is desired to move the said house, building or other structure, and the streets
and alleys along, over, upon and across which it is desired to move the same,
the length of time required to be fixed by the chief of police. (1961 Code)
4-4-2: SUFFICIENT BOND OR LIABILITY INSURANCE FILED:
Before a permit shall be granted by the said clerk, said applicant for said
permit must file with the city clerk a good and sufficient bond or liability
insurance policy in a sum to be fixed by the city clerk, saving and holding the
city harmless from any accident or damages that may result from the moving of
such house, building or other structure, which said bond shall be approved by
the attorney for the city. (1961 Code)
4-4-3: FILE CONTINUOUS BOND:
If the person, firm, or corporation making application for the permit provided
for in this chapter shall be regularly engaged in the business of moving
houses, buildings and other structures in the city, the said person, firm or
corporation may upon application to the city clerk be permitted to file a
continuing bond or liability insurance policy conditioned as provided in this
chapter, which said bond or insurance policy shall cover all the moving of
houses, buildings and other structures, in which the said person, firm, or
corporation may be engaged during the fiscal year in which said application is
made and thereafter it shall not be necessary for said person, firm or
corporation to file a separate bond or liability insurance policy with each and
every application for the permit provided for in this chapter. (1961 Code)
CHAPTER 5
GAS CODE
SECTION:
4-5-1: Definitions
4-5-2: Installation Standard
4-5-3: Installation Of Gas Service
4-5-4: Bond And Insurance
4-5-5: Industrial Use
4-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words, terms and phrases are
hereby defined and shall have the meaning herein given to them:
GAS: Natural gas suitable for domestic or industrial fuel.
GAS APPLIANCE: Any appliance or device used for burning gas.
GAS COMPANY: Any person or persons holding and exercising a franchise to
distribute gas within the corporate limits of the city.
GAS FITTER: Any person who does gas fitting work on any gas system or gas
appliance.
GAS FITTING SYSTEM: All gas piping, ductwork, appliances and accessories
installed or used in connection with consumption of gas on a consumer's
premises.
GAS FITTING WORK: The installation, alteration, extension, repair or
maintenance, from the outlet of the gas meter, of gas piping, venting and
appliances.
GAS INSTALLER: Any person who engages or employs gas fitters, servicemen, and/
or apprentices, to install gas equipment and accessories within the city.
GAS PIPING SYSTEM: All gas piping from the outlet of the gas meter installed or
used in connection with consumption of gas on a consumer's premises.
PERSON: Any person, firm, association, corporation or municipal corporation.
(Ord. 353, 6-10-1987)
4-5-2: INSTALLATION STANDARD:
Any gas company, gas installer or gas fitter installing gas appliances, gas
piping systems or gas fitting systems shall comply with the international fuel
gas code, 2012 edition, as prepared by the International Code Council, Inc.,
together with any amendments or revisions made by the Idaho building code board
through the negotiated rulemaking process, which effective January 1, 2015, is
hereby adopted as the fuel gas code of the city for any installation of gas
appliances and gas piping. Provisions for the issuance of permits and
collection of fees, and all regulations, conditions, provisions and terms of
such code is hereby adopted and made part hereof as if fully set forth in this
chapter. (Ord. 572, 12-10-2014)
4-5-3: INSTALLATION OF GAS SERVICE:
It shall be unlawful for any person other than an authorized employee of the
gas company to connect any gas appliance to any supply of fuel gas. (Ord. 353,
6-10-1987)
4-5-4: BOND AND INSURANCE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to undertake to install any gas appliance,
gas fitting system or gas piping system unless that person shall first obtain a
bond in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) secured by a surety
company authorized to do business in the state of Idaho. Such bond shall secure
the full performance of all provisions of law and regulations of the city
relating to gas fitting work and that any person injured by failure of the
principal to comply with such laws and regulations, or with any of the
provisions thereof, shall have the right of action against the principal and
surety in his name; provided that liability of any surety upon the bond
required to be given by the gas installer, as herein provided shall be limited
to the amount specified in the bond and in case of recoveries had by two (2) or
more persons for violations of the conditions of such bond in excess of the
amount of the bonds such recovery shall be prorated and the total recovery
against such surety shall not exceed the amount of the bond; provided further
that if any person wishing to avail himself of the benefits of the bond shall
commence action thereon within one year after the date of the completion of the
work alleged to have been improperly done.
Before any person undertakes to install any gas appliance, gas piping system or
gas fitting system, that person shall secure a comprehensive general liability
insurance policy issued by an insurance carrier authorized to do business in
the state of Idaho with a combined aggregate limit of five hundred thousand
dollars ($500,000.00) for losses on account of bodily or personal injury,
death, property damage or other loss as a result of any one occurrence or
accident regardless of the number of persons injured or the number of
claimants. (Ord. 353, 6-10-1987)
4-5-5: INDUSTRIAL USE:
Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to apply to the installation, use,
maintenance, alteration or repair of gas piping, gas fitting work, gas fitting
system, gas appliances and gas venting by any person, who has previously
installed natural gas for industrial use and performs its work through its
trained regularly employed journeymen, provided that such person shall comply
with all laws, rules and regulations in regard to proper gas installation.
(Ord. 353, 6-10-1987)
CHAPTER 6
UNSAFE BUILDINGS
SECTION:
4-6-1: Unsanitary And Dilapidated Buildings
4-6-2: Failure To Comply
4-6-3: Hearing
4-6-1: UNSANITARY AND DILAPIDATED BUILDINGS:
   A.   No person shall permit or suffer to be in or accumulate in, or upon any
yard, lot, place or premises or upon any street or sidewalk adjacent to or
abutting upon any lot, block, place or premises or in any building or shed
owned or occupied by him or them or for which he or they may be agents within
the limits of the city, any refuse, vegetable decay or decaying substance,
garbage or filth of any kind, nor suffer such yard, lot, place, building or
premises to be or to remain in such condition as unsightly or to cause or
create a nuisance or offensive smell or to pollute or render unhealthful the
atmosphere or the premises or thereby to be, become, cause or create a public
nuisance.
   B.   No person shall permit or suffer any yard, lot, place or premises, or
any building or shed owned or occupied by him or them or for which he or they
may be agents, within the limits of the city, in such dilapidated condition for
want of repairs or by reason of age, or from an other cause, which is
especially liable to fire or endangers the health, welfare, and safety of the
public in any way, or thereby to be, become, cause or create a public nuisance.
(Ord. 225, 3-8-1967)
4-6-2: FAILURE TO COMPLY:
Whenever a situation or condition advances to a state or deemed or determined
to be in violation of this chapter, the municipality, or its designated
official, shall notify and order such occupant or owner to remedy the same
within twenty (20) days following the date of notice. If the occupant or owner
fails to comply with the notice and order, the municipality may remove, repair
or remedy the condition and the cost thereof shall be assessed against the
premises or property so cleaned or cleared, such assessment to be certified by
the clerk to the county assessor and tax collector, who shall place the same
upon the tax roll for collection as a special tax in addition to the taxes for
general revenue purposes, and he shall collect the same in the manner and
subject to the same penalties as other city taxes. (Ord. 225, 3-8-1967)
4-6-3: HEARING:
In the event an occupant or owner desires a hearing on the matter, he may
notify the council in writing within five (5) days from date of notice and a
time and place will be set for the hearing. The running of the time required
for compliance shall be held in obeyance until the matter is decided. (Ord.
225, 3-8-1967)
TITLE 5
BUSINESS REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
AMUSEMENTS
SECTION:
5-1-1: License To Be Obtained Before Operation
5-1-2: Circuses And Sideshows License Fees
5-1-3: Booths, Stands Or Games
5-1-4: Tent Shows
5-1-5: Fortune Tellers, Palm Readers, Mind Readers, Phrenologists, Astrologers,
Clairvoyants
5-1-6: Merry Go Rounds And Rides
5-1-7: Carnivals
5-1-8: Consent Of Property Owners Near Mechanical Rides
5-1-9: Bond
5-1-1: LICENSE TO BE OBTAINED BEFORE OPERATION:
It shall be unlawful for any person, company or corporation to operate, engage
in or carry on any business, amusement or device as referred to in this chapter
without first obtaining a license therefor from the city clerk. (1961 Code)
5-1-2: CIRCUSES AND SIDESHOWS LICENSE FEES:
The keeper or proprietor of a circus or menagerie shall pay a license fee of
seventy five dollars ($75.00) per day and for each and every side show fifteen
dollars ($15.00) per day. (1961 Code)
5-1-3: BOOTHS, STANDS OR GAMES:
The proprietor or conductor of any booth, stand or game operated in connection
with or in proximity to a circus shall pay a license fee of five dollars
($5.00) per day. (1961 Code)
5-1-4: TENT SHOWS:
The keeper or proprietor of every tent show, other than a circus, for which a
charge is made shall pay a license fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per day.
(1961 Code)
5-1-5: FORTUNE TELLERS, PALM READERS, MIND READERS, PHRENOLOGISTS, ASTROLOGERS,
CLAIRVOYANTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to carry on the
occupation of fortune telling, palm reading, mind reading, phrenology,
astrology, clairvoyance, or any other means or device whereby the past or
future of any person is intended to be told, without first obtaining a license
from the city clerk so to do. The applicant for such a license must make out an
application form, furnished by the city clerk, giving his or her name, age,
place or location where business is to be carried on and furnish a true
likeness photograph of said applicant, such photograph to be attached to said
application form. The city clerk, before issuing such license, shall obtain the
approval of the city council to do so. The license fee for the herein mentioned
occupations shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) per day. No weekly or monthly
license rate reductions are provided for. Licenses are nontransferable. (1961
Code)
5-1-6: MERRY GO ROUNDS AND RIDES:
Merry go rounds and equipment of all kinds giving rides to people, to which an
admission is charged, are declared places of public entertainment and shall pay
a license fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per day if granted for less than a week,
and if granted for one week or more, then forty dollars ($40.00) per week and
sixty dollars ($60.00) per month. (1961 Code)
5-1-7: CARNIVALS:
A carnival, operated on the streets or in a vacant lot or place other than in a
building, shall be required to take out a license for each merry go round and
other apparatus giving rides, at the rates hereinbefore provided for the same,
and in addition shall pay a license at the rate of five dollars ($5.00) per day
for every booth, stand or game. (1961 Code)
5-1-8: CONSENT OF PROPERTY OWNERS NEAR MECHANICAL RIDES:
Any person who shall make application to the city clerk for a license to
conduct or operate any merry go round or mechanical device giving rides to
people shall at the same time of making such application file with the city
clerk a written statement, particularly describing the location of the place
where he desires to conduct or operate such mechanical rides which statement
shall have attached to it the written consent of four-fifths (4/5) of the
occupants of residence and business property within a radius of four hundred
feet (400') and no license shall be issued without such written consent being
filed. (1961 Code)
5-1-9: BOND:
Before a license be issued to a manager, owner or operator of a circus,
menagerie or carnival, such person shall be required to deposit with the city
clerk a cash bond of fifty dollars ($50.00), such bond to be a guarantee that
after the period during which the circus, menagerie or carnival is operated the
grounds or street or streets used for such operation be cleaned of all trash,
paper and other debris caused to be deposited thereon by said circus, menagerie
or carnival. Before returning said bond to the depositor, the city clerk shall
have such grounds, street or streets inspected for the purpose of ascertaining
that such cleaning has been done. (1961 Code)
CHAPTER 2
LICENSING AND REGULATING THEATERS
SECTION:
5-2-1: License Required; Application
5-2-2: Fee
5-2-3: Inspection
5-2-4: To Keep Aisles And Lobby Open
5-2-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION:
Before operating a theater within the city a license therefor shall be obtained
from the city clerk. The application for such license shall describe the
premises intended to be used, shall state the names and addresses of the owner
of the premises and of the proprietor of the business, shall have sufficient
evidence in connection with such application to establish that said theater and
its equipment and method of operation do and will conform with all building,
zoning, electrical, health and other applicable regulations of the city and the
state of Idaho; and shall contain such other information as may be deemed
necessary or advisable in the form of application which shall be furnished by
the city clerk. (1961 Code)
5-2-2: FEE:
There is an annual license fee to be paid to the city at the time of filing
such application for each theater to be licensed. All annual licenses shall
expire on December 31 following the issuance thereof. The license fee shall not
be prorated because of the fact that the license is issued for less than twelve
(12) months. (1961 Code; amd. per correspondence dated 6-15-2001)
5-2-3: INSPECTION:
It shall be the duty of any qualified person delegated by the mayor, to inspect
the place of business described in the application for a theater license prior
to the issuance of the license therein applied for, and also to make such
inspection, from time to time, to ensure that said place of business is, and
shall continue to be, suitable and safe for its use as a theater, and that all
regulations of the city and laws of the state of Idaho are being adhered to.
(1961 Code)
5-2-4: TO KEEP AISLES OPEN AND LOBBY OPEN:
No persons, other than ushers in the employ of the theater shall be allowed to
remain standing, and no chairs or seats shall be permitted to remain within any
of the aisles, passageways or in the lobby of the theater. (1961 Code)
CHAPTER 3
ADVERTISING AND BILLPOSTING
SECTION:
5-3-1: No Billposting Without A License
5-3-2: License, Terms
5-3-3: Littering Streets And Alleys With Posters
5-3-4: No Posting On Fences, Telegraph Poles; Consent For
5-3-1: NO BILLPOSTING WITHOUT A LICENSE:
No person or corporation shall engage in the distribution, posting, painting,
pasting or tacking of signs, bills, pictures or advertising matter announcing
the business or place or meeting of any entertainment, opera, theater,
menagerie or other exhibition of whatsoever nature or kind, or any other
advertising matter in any manner in the city except as hereinafter specified,
unless the said person or corporation shall first have been licensed as
hereinafter provided. (1961 Code)
5-3-2: LICENSE, TERMS:
Any person or corporation of good moral character desiring a license shall be
licensed by the city clerk to engage in the business of billposting, handbill
and sign advertising for the term of one year from the date of said license
upon the payment of the sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) to the city
treasurer. Conditioned that the said person or corporation shall perform such
duties in a good, lawful and proper manner in compliance with the provisions of
the city governing the character of the matter posted, painted or distributed
and the manner of posting, painting and distributing the same. (1961 Code)
5-3-3: LITTERING STREETS AND ALLEYS WITH POSTERS:
No person shall scatter or throw upon the streets, sidewalks or alleys of the
city, handbills, posters, advertisements or papers. Nothing herein shall be
construed to authorize any person to obstruct the streets, sidewalks, and
alleys of the city or create any nuisance therein. The provisions of this
chapter do not interfere or prevent the posting of notices required by law to
be posted. (1961 Code)
5-3-4: NO POSTING ON FENCES, TELEGRAPH POLES; CONSENT FOR:
No person or corporation shall post, paint, tack or otherwise attach any notice
or other advertising matter to any of the fences, walls or buildings or other
property in the city. The person or corporation shall first obtain the consent
of the owner of such property or his authorized agent or tenant. No person or
corporation shall post, paint, tack or otherwise attach any notices or
advertising matter to any of the telegraph, telephone, electric or other poles
in the streets or alleys of the city. (1961 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL REGULATIONS
SECTION:
5-4-1: Applicability
5-4-2: Purpose
5-4-1: APPLICABILITY:
   The provisions of this chapter shall be applicable to all wholesale and
retail businesses and all activities, occupational callings, trades, pursuits
or professions that conduct business from or at a location or locations within
the City of Kellogg or engage in any business, trade, or profession within the
geographic boundaries of the city of Kellogg with the object of gain, profit,
benefit or advantage. Each business location shall be deemed a separate
business unless it is a specific annex to the main location of the business.
The permit is not intended to repeal any permit, license or franchise
provisions of any other ordinance, nor is the permit to be considered a waiver
of any other requirements of compliance with any federal, state and local laws.
(Ord. 639, 4-9-2025)
5-4-2: PURPOSE:
   The purpose of this chapter is to assist in providing the city information
as to congestion, zoning, planning, street construction and utility
distribution. These standards are desired to protect and promote the public
welfare, health, and safety of persons within the community, and to aid in the
development and promotion of business and industry.
(Ord. 639, 4-9-2025)
CHAPTER 5
PARKING SINGLE TRAILER COACHES
(Rep. by Ord. 364, 4-5-1989)
CHAPTER 6
MOTELS
SECTION:
5-6-1: Building Permit Required
5-6-2: Service Station Restrictions
5-6-3: Parking Space On Premises
5-6-4: Minimum Size; Equipment
5-6-5: To Conform With Fire And Building Code
5-6-6: Application To Include Plan
5-6-7: Guests Required To Register
5-6-1: BUILDING PERMIT REQUIRED:
Before construction of a motor court is started, a permit for such construction
shall be obtained from the city clerk of the city for its approval. (1961 Code)
5-6-2: SERVICE STATION RESTRICTIONS:
Automobile service stations incidental to the facility shall be located no
closer than one hundred feet (100') to any unit. (1961 Code)
5-6-3: PARKING SPACE ON PREMISES:
Each unit of a motel or tourist court shall be provided with an assigned
parking space entirely on the premises. (1961 Code)
5-6-4: MINIMUM SIZE; EQUIPMENT:
The minimum space for each unit shall be twelve feet by twenty feet (12' x 20')
and shall contain a full bath, toilet facilities, dressing compartment and
sleeping room. (1961 Code)
5-6-5: TO CONFORM WITH FIRE AND BUILDING CODE:
The plumbing, heating, fenestration and ventilation components shall meet all
local fire and building code requirements. (1961 Code)
5-6-6: APPLICATION TO INCLUDE PLAN:
Each application for a motel or tourist court shall be submitted with a
complete plan, including the plot plan and adjacent buildings, parking
arrangement and driveways, unit sizes, plumbing and heating layout, accessory
uses, materials to be used, front and rear elevations and architectural design.
Permits shall be issued by the city clerk. (1961 Code)
5-6-7: GUESTS REQUIRED TO REGISTER:
Every operator of a motor court shall maintain a register in which each guest
of such motor court shall register his name, home address and license number of
the motor car in which he is traveling. The date of his arrival and departure
shall also be recorded. Such register shall be available to any authorized
person inspecting the motor court, and shall be preserved for a period not less
than one year. (1961 Code)
CHAPTER 7
PEDDLERS
SECTION:
5-7-1: Purpose Of Chapter
5-7-2: Nuisance Declared
5-7-3: Unlawful To Perpetrate Nuisance
5-7-4: Authorization To Abate
5-7-5: Exceptions
5-7-1: PURPOSE OF CHAPTER:
This chapter is passed to prevent and abate nuisances caused by peddlers,
hawkers, itinerant merchants and solicitors making uninvited entries in and
upon private residences. (1961 Code)
5-7-2: NUISANCES DECLARED:
The annoyances and disturbances attendant with the practice of engaging in
uninvited entries in and upon or trespassing in and upon private residences in
the city by peddlers, hawkers, itinerant merchants and solicitors of any kind
of goods, wares, commodities, merchandise, publications and pictures or
services for the purpose of canvassing, soliciting for orders or offering or
exposing for sale, goods, wares, commodities, merchandise, publications and
pictures or services, for the purpose of canvassing, soliciting for orders or
offering or exposing for sale goods, wares, commodities, merchandise,
publications and pictures or services, or disposing of and/or peddling or
hawking the same, is hereby declared a nuisance and such nuisance is punishable
as a misdemeanor as hereinafter set forth. (1961 Code)
5-7-3: UNLAWFUL TO PERPETRATE NUISANCE:
It shall be unlawful for any peddler, hawker, itinerant merchant, or solicitor
of any kind or character of goods, wares, commodities, merchandise,
publications, pictures, or services to perpetrate such a nuisance as described
in this chapter, and any person convicted of such a nuisance shall be guilty of
a misdemeanor. (1961 Code)
5-7-4: AUTHORIZATION TO ABATE:
The police authorities of the city are hereby authorized and directed to abate
said nuisance as described herein and arrest violators of this chapter and also
to suppress such nuisance. (1961 Code)
5-7-5: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the sale, or soliciting of
orders for the sale of milk, dairy products, vegetables, poultry, eggs, and
other farm and garden produce so far as the sale of the commodities named
herein is now authorized by law; provided, further, that such exempted
commodities must be produced in Idaho. (1961 Code)
CHAPTER 8
ITINERANT MERCHANTS
SECTION:
5-8-1: License Required
5-8-2: Definitions
5-8-3: Application
5-8-4: Investigation And Issuance
5-8-5: Bond
5-8-6: Service Of Process
5-8-7: Exhibition Of License
5-8-8: Fees
5-8-9: Transfer
5-8-10: Loud Noises And Speaking Devices
5-8-11: Duty Of Police To Enforce
5-8-12: Records
5-8-13: Revocation Of License
5-8-14: Appeal
5-8-15: Expiration Of License
5-8-16: Hours Of Door To Door Sale
5-8-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for a transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant
vendor as defined in this chapter to engage in such business within the city
without first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of
this chapter. (1961 Code)
5-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter a "transient merchant, itinerant merchant or
vendor" is defined as any person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, agent,
consignee, employee, whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in a
temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise
within said city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses
or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad box car, or
boat, public room in hotels, lodging houses, apartments, shops, or any place
within the city, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and
merchandise, either privately or at public auction provided that such
definition shall not be construed to include any person, firm or corporation
who, while occupying such temporary location, does not sell from stock, but
exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery
only. The person, firm or corporation so engaged shall not be relieved from
complying with the provisions of this chapter merely by reason of associating
temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, or be
conducting such transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in the
name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. (1961 Code)
5-8-3: APPLICATION:
Applicants for license under this chapter, whether a person, firm or
corporation, shall file a written sworn application signed by the applicant, if
an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by the president if a
corporation, with the city clerk, showing:
   A.   The name or names of the person or persons having the management or
supervision of applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it
will be carried on in the city, the local address or addresses of such person
or persons while engaged in such business; the permanent address or addresses
of such person or persons; the capacity in which such person or persons will
act (that is, whether as a proprietor, agent or otherwise); the name and
address of the person, firm or corporation for whose account the business will
be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the
same is incorporated;
   B.   The fingerprints of the person or persons having the management or
supervision of applicant's business or in lieu thereof, at least three (3)
letters of recommendation from reliable property owners in the county,
certifying as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or
other evidence which establishes to the satisfaction of the mayor the good
character and business responsibility of such person or persons;
   C.   The place or places in the city where it is proposed to carry on
applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposes that
said business will be conducted;
   D.   The place or places, other than the permanent place of business of the
applicant where applicant within the six (6) months next preceding the date of
said application conducted a transient business, stating the nature thereof and
giving the post office and street address of any building or office in which
such business was conducted;
   E.   A statement of the nature, character and quality of the goods, wares or
merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by applicant in the city, the
invoice value and quality of such goods, wares and merchandise, whether the
same are proposed to be sold from stock in possession or from stock in
possession and by sample; at auction, by direct sale or by taking orders for
future delivery; where the goods or property proposed to be sold are
manufactured or produced and where such goods or products are located at the
time said application is filed;
   F.   A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done
or proposed to be done in order to attract customers, and, if required by the
clerk, copies of all said advertising whether by handbills, circular, newspaper
advertising or otherwise, shall be attached to said application as exhibits
thereto;
   G.   Whether or not the person or persons having the management or
supervision of the applicant's business have been convicted of a crime,
misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such
offense and the punishment assessed therefor;
   H.   Credentials from the person, firm or corporation for which the
applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such
representative; and
   I.   Such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of
the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's
business or the method or plan of doing such business as the city clerk may
deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this chapter in the protection of the
public good. (1961 Code)
5-8-4: INVESTIGATION AND ISSUANCE:
Upon receipt of such application the city clerk shall cause such investigation
of such person's or persons' business responsibility or moral character to be
made as he deems necessary to the protection of the public good. If, as a
result of such investigation, the applicant's character and business
responsibility are found to be unsatisfactory, the application shall be denied.
If, as a result of the investigation, the character and business reputation
appear to be satisfactory, the city clerk shall so certify in writing, and a
license shall be issued by the city clerk. The city clerk shall keep a full
record in his office of all licenses issued. Such license shall contain the
number of the license, the date the same is issued, the nature of the business
authorized to be carried on, the amount of the license fee paid, the expiration
date of said license, the place where said business may be carried on under
said license, and the name or names of the person or persons authorized to
carry on the same. (1961 Code)
5-8-5: BOND:
Before any license, as provided by this chapter shall be issued for engaging in
a transient or itinerant business as defined in this chapter in the city, such
applicant shall file with the city clerk a bond running to the city in the sum
of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) executed by the applicant, as principal,
and two (2) sureties upon which service of process may be made in the state of
Idaho; said bond to be approved by the city attorney, conditioned that the said
applicant shall comply fully with all the provisions of the ordinances of the
city and the statutes of the state of Idaho regulating and concerning the sale
of goods, wares and merchandise, and will pay all judgments rendered against
said applicant for any violation of said laws or statutes, or any of them
together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against him by any
person or persons for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deception
practiced on any person or persons transacting such business with such
applicant, whether said misrepresentations or deceptions were made or practices
by the owners or by their servants, agents, or employees, either at the time of
making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever,
printed, or circulated with reference to the goods, wares and merchandise sold
or any part thereof. Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city
to the use of the aggrieved person. Such bond must be approved by the city
attorney, both as to form and as to the responsibility of the sureties thereon.
(1961 Code)
5-8-6: SERVICE OF PROCESS:
Before any license as herein provided shall be issued for engaging in business
as an itinerant merchant as herein defined in the city, such applicant shall
file with the city clerk an instrument nominating and appointing the city
clerk, or the person performing the duties of such position, his true and
lawful agent with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of
process for and on behalf of said applicant in respect to any matter connected
with or arising out of the business transacted under said license and the bond
given as required by this chapter, or for the performance of the conditions of
said bond or for any breach thereof, which said instrument shall also contain
recitals to the effect that said applicant for said consents and agrees that
service of any notice or process may be made upon said agent, and when so made
shall be taken and held to be as valid as if personally served upon the person
or persons applying for the said license under this chapter, according to the
law of this or any other state, and waiving all claim or right of error by
reason of such acknowledgement of service or manner of service. Immediately
upon service or process upon the city clerk, as herein provided, the city clerk
shall send to the licensee at his last known address, by registered mail, a
copy of said process. (1961 Code)
5-8-7: EXHIBITION OF LICENSE:
The license issued under this chapter shall be posted conspicuously in the
place of business named therein. In the event that such person or persons
applying for said license shall desire to do business in more than one place in
the city, separate licenses may be issued for each place of business, and shall
be posted conspicuously in each place of business. (1961 Code)
5-8-8: FEES:
Licensees under this chapter shall pay a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) per
day, payable in advance. (1961 Code)
5-8-9: TRANSFER:
No license shall be transferred. (1961 Code)
5-8-10: LOUD NOISES AND SPEAKING DEVICES:
No licensee under this chapter, nor anyone in his behalf shall shout, make an
outcry, blow a horn, ring a bell or use any other sound device including any
loudspeaking radio or amplifying system upon any of the streets, alleys, parks
or other public places in the said city or upon any premises in the said city
where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom capable of
being plainly heard upon the streets, avenues, alleys or parks or other public
places, for the purpose of attracting attention to any goods, wares or
merchandise which such licensee proposes to sell. (1961 Code)
5-8-11: DUTY OF POLICE TO ENFORCE:
It shall be the duty of the police officers of the city to examine all places
of business and persons in their respective territories subject to the
provisions of this chapter, to determine if this chapter has been complied with
and to enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found to be
violating the same. (1961 Code)
5-8-12: RECORDS:
The city clerk shall deposit the record of fingerprints of licensee, together
with a license number with the chief of police. The chief of police shall
report to the city clerk any complaints against any person licensed under the
provisions of this chapter and any conviction for violation of this chapter,
the city clerk shall keep a record of all such licenses and of such complaints
and violations. (1961 Code)
5-8-13: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   The permits and licenses issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked
by the mayor of the city after notice and hearing for any of the following
reasons:
      1.   Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the
application for license;
      2.   Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in
connection with the selling of goods, wares or merchandise;
      3.   Any violation of this chapter;
      4.   Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor
involving moral turpitude; or
      5.   Conducting the business licensed under this chapter in an unlawful
manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to
constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public.
   B.   Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in
writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time
and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid to the
licensee, at his last known address, at least five (5) days prior to the date
set for the hearing. (1961 Code)
5-8-14: APPEAL:
Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city clerk in regard to the denial
of application for license as provided for in this chapter or in connection
with the revocation of a license as herein provided, shall have the right to
appeal to the council of the city. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with
the council within fourteen (14) days after notice of the decision by the city
clerk has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement
setting forth the grounds for the appeal. The council shall set the time and
place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to
such person in the same manner as provided in this chapter for notice of
hearing on revocation. The order of this council on such appeal shall be final.
(1961 Code)
5-8-15: EXPIRATION OF LICENSE:
All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire ninety
(90) days after the date of issuance thereof unless a prior date is fixed
therein. (1961 Code)
5-8-16: HOURS OF DOOR TO DOOR SALE:
No person shall sell door to door or solicit for sale or petition between the
hours of six o'clock (6:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. according to the
standard of time recognized by the city. (Ord. 551, 3-9-2011)
CHAPTER 9
PHOTOGRAPHERS
SECTION:
5-9-1: Definition
5-9-2: License Required For Resident Photographer
5-9-3: License Fee Of Resident Photographer
5-9-4: Definition Of Transient Photographer
5-9-5: License Required For Transient Photographer
5-9-6: License Fee Of Transient Photographer
5-9-1: DEFINITION:
The term photographer in this chapter shall include any person, firm or
corporation engaged in the business of taking pictures or views by or with
photographic equipment whether said business is carried on as a sideline to the
sale of merchandise other than pictures or solely carried on for the purpose of
dealing in pictures. It shall also include persons engaged in the business of
engraving, retouching or reconditioning photographs. (Ord. 268, 2-7-1973)
5-9-2: LICENSE REQUIRED FOR RESIDENT PHOTOGRAPHER:
Any resident person, firm or corporation conducting the business of photography
in the city shall first obtain a license from the city clerk authorizing him
and/or them to carry on such business. (Ord. 268, 2-7-1973)
5-9-3: LICENSE FEE OF RESIDENT PHOTOGRAPHER:
The license fee for any resident person, firm or corporation conducting the
business of photography in the city shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) per year,
payable on January 1. (Ord. 268, 2-7-1973)
5-9-4: DEFINITION OF TRANSIENT PHOTOGRAPHER:
A "transient photographer", for the purpose of this chapter, is hereby defined
as any itinerant photographer, picture or view taker, coupon salesman,
enlargement solicitor or canvasser therefor, not residing in and/or conducting
said business in said city for a period of at least one full calendar month,
after which he is considered a resident photographer and shall be entitled to
the rights and privileges thereof, and a refund of all money in excess of the
regular resident photographer fees. (Ord. 268, 2-7-1973)
5-9-5: LICENSE REQUIRED FOR TRANSIENT PHOTOGRAPHER:
No person, firm or corporation shall engage in or follow the business or
occupation of a transient photographer within the city without first having
obtained a license therefor from the city clerk of the city. (Ord. 268, 2-7-
1973)
5-9-6: LICENSE FEE OF TRANSIENT PHOTOGRAPHER:
The license fee for any transient person, firm or corporation carrying on the
business of photography in the city, shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per day for
each and every person engaged in, assisting, soliciting, touching up, or in any
way connected with such business. Providing however, that when any person, firm
or corporation shall buy, purchase, or in any legal way acquire a legally
established business within the city he shall be entitled to resident license
rates immediately. (Ord. 268, 2-7-1973)
CHAPTER 10
BEER REGULATIONS
SECTION:
5-10-1: Definitions
5-10-2: Alcoholic Content
5-10-3: License Required
5-10-4: Application Form
5-10-5: Annual License Limited In Number Issued
5-10-6: License Fee
5-10-7: Qualifications Of Licensee
5-10-8: Power To Refuse, Revoke And Inspect
5-10-9: Licenses Transferable
5-10-10: To Post License
5-10-11: Sale In Private Residence Prohibited
5-10-12: Soliciting Sales Prohibited
5-10-13: Limitations On Age Prescribed
5-10-14: Open Container Of Beer In Or On Public Highways, Streets, Sidewalks Or
Parking Lots Prohibited
5-10-15: Hours Of Sale
5-10-16: Loaning Of Money Or Credit Prohibited
5-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
BEER: Any beverage obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of any infusion or
decoction of barley, kale and/or other ingredients in drinkable water.
RETAILER: Any person engaged in the sale or distribution of beer to the
consumer. (1961 Code)
5-10-2: ALCOHOLIC CONTENT:
Beer containing not more than four percent (4%) of alcohol by weight may be
sold and distributed in the city, or possessed therein in the manner and under
the conditions prescribed in this chapter and not otherwise. It shall be
unlawful to sell and dispose of, or possess for the purpose of retail sale,
beer of any kind or character of any alcoholic content greater than herein
prescribed or other than in the manner permitted by this chapter. (1961 Code)
5-10-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to sell at retail to
the consumer any beer within the corporate limits of the city, without first
obtaining a license therefor from the said city, and a separate license shall
be required for each place of business where beer is sold. (1961 Code)
5-10-4: APPLICATION FORM:
All applications for licenses must be in writing and filed with the city clerk
upon forms, provided by the city, and such applications must be accompanied by
the license fee prescribed herein, and shall specify:
   A.   The name, age and citizenship of the applicant if an individual, and if
a corporation, the name of the state or county in which corporated, its
principal place of business, together with its principal place of business in
Idaho, and the names and places of residence of its designated agent in Idaho,
and if a partnership, the names and residences of all partners.
   B.   If the application is made by an individual, a statement as to whether
or not he is a citizen of the United States and if so, when and where born, if
a naturalized citizen, the time and place and where he was naturalized.
   C.   The length of time the applicant has resided in the city and if a
corporation, when and where it first commenced to do business in Idaho.
   D.   The city council shall grant or deny the application within thirty (30)
days of the time it is filed with the city clerk. Prior to any revocation or
suspension the licensee shall be afforded a hearing according to section 23-
1016, Idaho Code. Whenever the mayor and city council deny an application, they
shall specify in writing:
      1.   The statutes, ordinances and standards used in evaluating the
application;
      2.   The reason for the denial; and
      3.   The actions, if any, that the applicant could take to obtain the
license, transfer or renewal thereof.
   In all cases where the city council is considering applications for
licenses, transfers, or renewals thereof, a transcribable verbatim record of
the proceeding shall be made. If the applicant for a license, transfer or
renewal is denied, a transcribable, verbatim record of the proceedings shall be
kept for a period of not less than six (6) months after a final decision on the
matter. Upon written request and within the time period provided for retention
of the record, any person may have the record transcribed at his expense. The
city council shall also provide for the keeping of the minutes of the
proceedings. Minutes shall be retained indefinitely or as otherwise provided by
law.
   No license shall be granted hereunder until there has been an investigation
by the police department of all applicants hereunder. After investigation the
applications will be forwarded to the city council with a recommendation from
the chief of police. If the chief of police recommended that an application be
denied, he shall state in writing:
      1.   The statutes or ordinances and standards used in evaluating the
application;
      2.   The reason for the denial; and
      3.   The action, if any, that the applicant could take to obtain the
license, transfer or renewal thereof. (Ord. 333, 4-11-1984)
5-10-5: ANNUAL LICENSE LIMITED IN NUMBER ISSUED:
Such licenses shall in the first instance be issued for the remainder of the
then current year and thereafter shall be reissued or renewed for the full
period of one calendar year. All licenses shall expire on December 31 of the
year in which they were issued. No license shall be issued for a shorter period
of time than one year, except as herein provided. There shall not be issued in
excess of four (4) licenses of each classification as the same are defined for
licensing purposes herein in this chapter per each one thousand (1,000)
population or fraction thereof. (1961 Code)
5-10-6: LICENSE FEE:
The retailer desiring to engage in the retail sale of beer shall apply to the
city for a retail license and shall pay an annual license fee as follows:
   A.   Where such retailer sells only bottled or canned beer, none of which is
consumed on the premises where sold, the annual license fee shall be fifty
dollars ($50.00).
   B.   Where such retailer sells only bottled or canned beer which is consumed
on the premises where sold, the annual license fee shall be one hundred fifty
dollars ($150.00).
   C.   Where such retailer sells draught beer and bottled or canned beer, or
draught beer only, the annual license fee shall be two hundred dollars
($200.00).
The license fee herein provided shall be paid in advance and expiration date of
the license issued as herein provided shall be one year from the date of
issuance. (Ord. 322, 9-8-1981)
5-10-7: QUALIFICATIONS OF LICENSEE:
No license to sell beer at retail shall be granted except to a person of good
moral character and/or repute and nineteen (19) years of age or over; nor shall
any such license be granted to any applicant who is not a citizen of the United
States, or who has not been a bona fide resident of the state of Idaho for a
period of one year prior to the date of making application, or who shall have
been convicted for the violation of any law of Idaho or the United States
regulating, governing or prohibiting the sale of alcoholic beverage or
intoxicating liquor; provided, however, that in case the applicant is a
partnership, the requirements relative to residence shall be deemed satisfied
when any member of the partnership, or the actual manager thereof has been a
bona fide resident of the state of Idaho for a period of one year prior to date
of making such application, nor shall any such license be granted to any
applicant who has not been granted a license to sell beer at retail by the
county in the event said county license such sales, nor shall any person be
permitted to receive or hold a license under this chapter for use in connection
with any business not under the personal supervision, management and control of
said person to whom said license is issued. (Ord. 270, 5-9-1973)
5-10-8: POWER TO REFUSE, REVOKE AND INSPECT:
The city council shall have the power to refuse a license to any applicant and/
or revoke a license at any time when in the judgment of said city council the
business interests and the welfare of the city and/or the inhabitants, thereof,
will be best served by the denial or revocation thereof; and for the purpose of
ascertaining whether or not any licensee is conforming with the provisions of
this and other chapters of the city as well as the laws of the state of Idaho,
the police of the city shall have the right at all reasonable times to inspect
the places where beer is sold under the licenses issued. (1961 Code)
5-10-9: LICENSES TRANSFERABLE:
No person shall be granted more than one license for any one year, but the
council in its discretion, may permit the location of the place of business
designated in the license to be changed, without any charge therefor.
Licenses issued under the provisions hereof may be transferred upon proper
application, provided that any proposed transferee shall meet all of the
conditions and qualifications of a licensee under this chapter. Applications
for a transfer of a license shall be accompanied by a fee of five dollars
($5.00), shall contain all of the information required in a license
application, and shall be subject to the approval of the mayor and the council.
Upon approval the license shall be endorsed over to the transferee by said
licensee for the remainder of the period for which said license has been issued
and the city clerk shall note on said license the approval of the transfer by
the mayor and council. (1961 Code)
5-10-10: TO POST LICENSE:
It shall be the duty of each person to whom a license is issued under this
chapter to keep the same at all times posted in a conspicuous place in his
place of business. (1961 Code)
5-10-11: SALE IN PRIVATE RESIDENCE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale, beer at any
private dwelling, apartment house, lodging house, or private room used for
dwelling purposes in the city. (1961 Code)
5-10-12: SOLICITING SALES PROHIBITED:
No license shall be issued hereunder for the sale of, nor shall any person
acting under such license, sell beer by peddling or in any way soliciting
orders for the same, and no sale shall be made except in the place for which
the license has been granted, provided, however, that any licensee may accept
orders left at his place of business by a purchaser and/or consumer and make
delivery thereof. (1961 Code)
5-10-13: LIMITATIONS ON AGE PRESCRIBED:
It shall be unlawful to sell beer to or by any person under the age of twenty
(20) years. (1961 Code)
5-10-14: OPEN CONTAINER OF BEER IN OR ON PUBLIC HIGHWAYS, STREETS, SIDEWALKS OR
PARKING LOTS PROHIBITED:
No person shall have an open container of beer upon any public highway, or
street or sidewalk or parking lot within the limits of the city. (Ord. 305, 6-
14-1978)
5-10-15: HOURS OF SALE:
It shall be unlawful for any licensed beer dispenser within the city to sell or
to otherwise dispose of beer within the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and
six o'clock (6:00) A.M. according to the standard of time recognized by the
city or to permit such beverages to be possessed, consumed or drunk upon the
premises under the control of such licensed dispenser of beer, with no
consumption after two thirty o'clock (2:30) A.M., as allowed per Idaho Code 23-
1012(2) and 23-1012(4). (Ord. 543, 2-10-2010)
5-10-16: LOANING OF MONEY OR CREDIT PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any licensed beer dispenser to advance money or credit
on the security of personal property pledged or deposited in said licensee's
keeping without keeping a written daily record of the following:
   A.   An accurate description of the personal property pledged or deposited.
   B.   Name, residence address and description of the person or persons from
whom said personal property is received.
   C.   The date when said personal property is received. Said record shall be
open to the inspection of any police officer of the city at all times during
regular business hours of said licensee. (1961 Code)
CHAPTER 11
LIQUOR BY THE DRINK
SECTION:
5-11-1: Purpose Of Chapter
5-11-2: License Required
5-11-3: Application For License
5-11-4: Qualifications
5-11-5: License Fee
5-11-6: Issuance Of License
5-11-7: Licenses Transferable
5-11-8: State Law Violation
5-11-9: Grounds For Revocation Of License
5-11-10: Hours Of Sale And City Option On Days Of Sale
5-11-1: PURPOSE OF CHAPTER:
This chapter is passed pursuant to and under the authority of provisions of
chapter 274 of the Idaho session laws of 1947. (1961 Code)
5-11-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be lawful for any person to sell liquor by the drink at retail within
the corporate limits of the city after having first procured a license as
hereinafter provided. (1961 Code)
5-11-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for license shall be in writing signed and sworn to be the
applicant upon application forms furnished by the city clerk and presented to
the mayor and city council at the next regular meeting of the said council for
their approval, rejection or further consideration. (1961 Code)
5-11-4: QUALIFICATIONS:
The applicant for a license shall possess all of the qualifications necessary
to obtain a license from the commissioner of law enforcement of the state of
Idaho, as prescribed, and maintain such qualifications throughout the period
for which such license is issued. The possession of a license regularly issued
by the department of law enforcement of the state of Idaho shall be prima facie
evidence of the applicant's qualifications to receive a license hereunder.
(1961 Code)
5-11-5: LICENSE FEE:
The license fee imposed and collected shall be the sum of five hundred sixty
two dollars fifty cents ($562.50) per annum for the license year, within which
