safety officer or a police officer may seize, impound and humanely confine to
an animal shelter or hospital any of the following animals:
      1.   Any dog without a valid license tag;
      2.   Any animal at large;
      3.   Any animal constituting a public nuisance or considered a danger to
the public;
      4.   Any animal that is in violation of any quarantine or confinement
order of the Panhandle Health District, a Kellogg animal safety officer or any
standing quarantine or confinement order of any public officer;
      5.   Any unattended animal that is ill, injured or otherwise in need of
care;
      6.   Any animal that is reasonably believed to have been abused or
neglected;
      7.   Any animal that is reasonably suspected of having rabies;
      8.   Any animal that is charged with being potentially dangerous, or
dangerous where the City Council or animal safety officer determines that there
is a threat to public health and safety, including illegal exotic and wild
animals;
      9.   Any animal that a court of competent jurisdiction has ordered
impounded or destroyed;
      10.   Any animal that is considered unattended or abandoned, as in
situations where the owner is deceased, has been arrested or has been evicted
from his/her regular place of residence;
      11.   Any animal that has been declared vicious and the owner or
caretaker fails to adhere the established guidelines set forth in the vicious
animal guidelines as set forth in section
6-4-17 of this chapter.
   B.   An animal safety officer or police officer may also, or in lieu of
impoundment of an animal running at large (other than domestic cats), issue to
the owner a notice of violation which calls for payment of an animal control
fee or, in the alternative, may issue an infraction citation charging the owner
with a violation of this chapter. Any animal owner issued a notice of violation
shall pay any animal control fee established by resolution to the City within
thirty (30) days of the date the notice of violation is issued. Such fee may be
paid at the location noted on the notice of violation. In the event that such
fee is not paid within the time period prescribed, the animal safety officer or
police officer may issue a uniform citation or refer the matter to the City
Prosecutor in order to initiate misdemeanor criminal proceedings for the
underlying violation of this chapter. Such citation or complaint shall be
punishable as a criminal misdemeanor as otherwise provided by this Code. (Ord.
591, 10-11-2017)
6-4-19: NOTICE TO OWNER AND REDEMPTION:
   A.   Upon impoundment of an animal, the animal safety officer may attempt to
notify the owner by telephone or mail. If the owner is unknown or cannot be
contacted, the animal safety officer shall post written notice for three (3)
working days at the Kellogg City Hall, describing the animal and the time and
place of taking. Any notice to the owner may also include the location of the
shelter or hospital where the animal is confined, hours during which the animal
can be reclaimed, and the fees to be charged to the owner. The owner may also
be advised that the failure to claim the animal within three (3) working days
may result in the destruction or other disposition of the animal.
   B.   An owner reclaiming an impounded animal shall pay impound fees as
established by resolution of the City Council. The rates charged for any
subsequent impoundment may likewise be established by resolution of the City
Council.
   C.   Any animal not reclaimed by its owner within three (3) working days
shall be subject to placement for adoption in a suitable home or euthanized in
a humane manner prescribed by the City. (Ord. 591, 10-11-2017)
6-4-20: PROPERTY OWNERS MAY IMPOUND:
Any person finding an animal at large upon his/her property may remove the same
to any animal shelter that will take possession of the animal. Any person doing
so shall inform the shelter operator of the location where the animal was
captured, type of animal, and any other information which may be relevant to
locating the owner or circumstance concerning the animal. If no such shelter is
available, the property owner may humanely hold the animal in his/her own
possession and immediately notify the animal safety officer. The property owner
shall provide a description of the animal and the name of the owner if known.
(Ord. 591, 10-11-2017)
6-4-21: RETURN OF ANIMAL TO OWNER:
If the name of the owner or custodian of an animal found at large is known or
can be obtained with reasonable dispatch, the animal safety officer may attempt
contact with such owner and advise the owner of the location of the animal and
attempt to make arrangements to return the animal. If the animal owner is not
available, the animal safety officer may provide written notice to the
registered owner explaining who the owner must contact to reclaim the animal.
The officer may remove the animal to the nearest shelter that will accept the
animal. The ultimate responsibility for locating an impounded animal is the
owner's. (Ord. 591, 10-11-2017)
6-4-22: DISPOSITION OF LARGE ANIMALS:
Any animal safety officer or other designated person on call who removes or
takes custody of a healthy large animal such as a horse, cow, mule or other
animal, which is not acceptable to any animal hospital or shelter, shall be
authorized to call a trucking firm or company which may convey the animal to a
farm or other appropriate facility that will accept such animals. The
disposition of any animal removed to a facility other than an animal hospital
or shelter shall be handled in the same manner as though the animal were
confined in an animal hospital or shelter. Any such expenses of shelter or care
shall be the responsibility of the owner. (Ord. 591, 10-11-2017)
6-4-23: LICENSING OF DOGS:
   A.   License Required: No person shall own, keep, or harbor any dog over the
age of six (6) months within the City unless such dog is licensed as provided
in this chapter.
   B.   Application: Application for such license shall be made by the owner on
a form to be provided by the City within ten (10) days after acquiring any dog
over six (6) months of age or within ten (10) days after a dog becomes six (6)
months of age; provided that any owner moving to the City for the purposes of
establishing residence or becoming a resident as a result of any annexation,
and otherwise required to obtain a license, shall have until thirty (30) days
after establishing residence to obtain such license.
   C.   Proof Of Rabies Vaccination Required: All owners applying for a license
must show to the satisfaction of the licensing authority that the dog for which
the license is being obtained has been inoculated against rabies within the
last two (2) years.
   D.   Proof Of Sterilization: Any owner claiming that his/her dog has been
spayed or neutered must show to the satisfaction of the licensing authority
that the operation has been performed.
   E.   Payment Of License Fee: A license fee shall be paid at the time of
making application. The license fee for dogs shall be established by the City
Council by resolution. Such fee may be different depending upon the altered
status.
   F.   Exemption From License Fee: License fees shall not be required for
seeing eye dogs, dogs prescribed by a doctor for medical reasons, government
police dogs or dogs belonging to a nonresident of the City (which are licensed
elsewhere) and kept within the boundaries of the City for not longer than
thirty (30) days; provided that all dogs not subject to payment of the license
fee shall at the time of entry into the City be properly vaccinated against
rabies, and while kept within the City, meet all other requirements of this
chapter. Any owner claiming any of these exemptions has the burden of proving
to the satisfaction of the licensing authority that the dog in question is
entitled to such exemption.
   G.   Penalties: Any owner of a dog over the age of six (6) months who fails
to obtain a license within the time period specified in this chapter shall be
subject to a fee set by the City Council by resolution and/or shall be subject
to prosecution for violation of this chapter as otherwise provided herein.
(Ord. 591, 10-11-2017)
6-4-24: LICENSE TAGS; IDENTIFICATION:
   A.   Upon payment and acceptance of the license fee, the City shall issue a
durable license tag, stamped with an identification number for the dog for
which the license has been obtained. Any license issued for the keeping of a
dog shall take effect on the date of issuance and shall be valid for the period
of time paid for and shown on the receipt issued by the licensing authority.
Every dog for which the owner is required to obtain a license must wear a valid
license tag at all times when the dog is off the premises of its owner.
   B.   No person may use a license for any dog other than the dog for which
the license was issued. It shall be unlawful for any person except the licensed
owner to remove from the neck of any dog the license tag issued pursuant to
this section. It shall further be unlawful for any person to alter such tag in
any manner.
   C.   Any dog license issued in reliance of false or inaccurate information
may be revoked. Anyone who knowingly submits false information to obtain a
license or to obtain a license without paying the appropriate fee shall be
deemed to have violated this chapter and shall be subject to all potential
penalties therefor. (Ord. 591, 10-11-2017)
6-4-25: VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES:
   A.   It shall be a violation of this chapter to:
      1.   Fail to comply with any provision of this chapter, that is, to do
that which is described as unlawful or to violate the requirements established
by this chapter;
      2.   Fail to comply with any lawful order of the animal safety officer or
police officer, unless such order is lawfully stayed or reversed.
   B.   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter, shall be deemed
guilty of an infraction and may be punished as provided in title 1, chapter 15
of this Code. Should any person be found guilty in any court of competent
jurisdiction, the court may order the animal involved to be destroyed by the
animal safety officer.
   C.   The City may undertake civil legal action in a court of competent
jurisdiction to seek to enjoin conduct which violates the provisions of this
chapter and/or to recover the reasonable costs of actions deemed necessary to
bring about compliance herewith.
   D.   Any violation of this chapter shall be punishable as follows: Any
person who violates any provision of this chapter may be issued a civil
citation in lieu of a uniform infraction citation and shall be assessed a civil
penalty as follows:
      1.   First violation: Fifty dollars ($50.00).
      2.   Second violation within two (2) years of first violation: One
hundred dollars ($100.00).
      3.   Third violation within two (2) years of first violation: One hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00).
      4.   Fourth and subsequent violations within two (2) years of first
violation: Two hundred dollars ($200.00).
   The civil citation assessment shall be payable at City Hall within thirty
(30) days from the date of issuance. No partial payments will be accepted as
full payment. If, within the thirty (30) day period following the issuance of
the City civil citation the assessment has not been paid, an infraction uniform
citation or sworn complaint may be issued for the violation of this chapter or
the rules, and the violator, if found guilty, will be fined in the appropriate
above amount for the violation plus court costs. Nothing contained herein
prohibits a law enforcement officer from issuance of a uniform infraction
citation instead of a civil citation. (Ord. 591, 10-11-2017)
CHAPTER 5
GENERAL OFFENSES
SECTION:
6-5-1: General Offense
6-5-2: False Representation
6-5-3: Resisting An Officer
6-5-4: Aid In Escape
6-5-5: Assault Or Battery
6-5-6: Unlawful Assembly
6-5-7: Open Container Of Beer, Wine, Liquor, Or Other Alcoholic Beverage In
Public Prohibited
6-5-8: Breach Of The Peace
6-5-9: Petit Larceny
6-5-10: Unlawful Use Of Utility
6-5-11: False Pretenses
6-5-12: Vagrancy (Rep. by Ord. 431, 3-12-1997)
6-5-13: Disorderly Conduct
6-5-14: Prostitution
6-5-15: House Of Prostitution
6-5-16: Aid To An Offense
6-5-17: Barbed Wire And Electric Fences
6-5-18: Cruelty To Animals
6-5-19: Distribution Of Obscene Literature (Rep. by Ord. 431, 3-12-1997)
6-5-20: Sale Of Cigarettes Or Tobacco To Minors
6-5-21: Expectorating On Sidewalks Or In Public Buildings
6-5-22: Minors In Pool Halls (Rep. by Ord. 431, 3-12-1997)
6-5-23: Water Flowing Upon Streets
6-5-24: Deposits Of Injurious Material On Thoroughfares
6-5-25: Lug Wheels Prohibited
6-5-26: Keeping Of Junk Prohibited
6-5-27: Loudspeakers
6-5-28: Minors; Liquor Offenses
6-5-29: Malicious Injury To Property
6-5-30: Noise
6-5-31:    Camping On Public Property
6-5-1: GENERAL OFFENSE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any act or fail to perform any
requirement within the City which is prohibited or required by State law,
insofar as such laws, are applicable to Municipal government. (1961 Code)
6-5-2: FALSE REPRESENTATION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself to be an
officer of the Municipality or who shall attempt to impersonate any such
officer or who shall without authority perform any official act therein on
behalf of an officer all within the limits of the City. (1961 Code)
6-5-3: RESISTING AN OFFICER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, resist, molest or
threaten to molest any officer of the Municipality in the exercise of his
official duties within the City. (1961 Code)
6-5-4: AID IN ESCAPE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to aid or assist any person to escape from
lawful confinement, or who shall assist any person to escape from the custody
of any peace officer within the City. (1961 Code)
6-5-5: ASSAULT OR BATTERY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit assault or battery as defined by
sections 18-901 and 18-903, Idaho Code, within the City. (1961 Code)
6-5-6: UNLAWFUL ASSEMBLY:
It shall be unlawful for two (2) or more persons to assemble together within
the City for the purpose of disturbing the peace or for the purpose of
committing an unlawful act, and do not disburse upon the command so to do by an
officer, the persons so offending shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.
(1961 Code)
6-5-7: OPEN CONTAINER OF BEER, WINE, LIQUOR, OR OTHER ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE IN
PUBLIC PROHIBITED:
   A.   No person shall have or possess any open or opened container or
receptacle of beer, wine, liquor, or any other alcoholic beverage within the
City of Kellogg, upon any public highway, street, sidewalk, park, parking lot,
or other public place, which includes any motor vehicle, whether moving or
parked upon such place. For the purposes of this specific section, "public"
means any property owned by the state of Idaho, the city of Kellogg, or any
other political subdivision of the state of Idaho, and also includes unenclosed
privately owned property open to the general public; however, this section
shall not apply to any premises duly licensed for the sale and consumption of
beer, wine, liquor, or other alcoholic beverage in question.
   B.   Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection A of this section, the
city council shall have the authority to issue permits for the possession and
consumption of beer and/or wine at the Kellogg Memorial city park located at 2
North Hill Street, and the town square located on the north end of Main Street,
and to any licensed retailer of beer and wine by the drink for private property
adjacent to the licensed premises. Said permits may be issued to political,
fraternal, civic, and other similar established groups or organizations and to
licensed retail sellers of beer and/or wine by the drink for appropriate
functions at a specified date and time. Application for such a permit shall be
made to the city council on a form approved by the council, which shall require
at a minimum, the name of the group, organization or retailer, a brief
description of the nature and purpose of the particular function, and an
estimate of the number of people expected to attend. The application shall be
signed and dated by an authorized representative of the group, organization or
retailer making the application and shall recite an acknowledgment that, if
granted the beer and wine permit, said group or organization agrees to fully
defend and indemnify the city of Kellogg and its officers and employees from
any civil liability, damage, or loss in any way resulting from issuance of the
permit. All applications shall be filed with the council at least five (5) days
prior to the date of the scheduled council meeting immediately preceding the
date of the proposed function for which application for the beer and wine
permit is being made. Applications for a beer and wine permit shall be approved
when, in a majority of the council's judgment, it is deemed to be in the
interest of the public good. (Ord. 419, 10-16-1996)
6-5-8: BREACH OF THE PEACE:
It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to commit a breach of the
peace, by loud or vulgar language, noisy acclamations or by doing anything that
shall be offensive to the sense or dangerous to the peace. (1961 Code)
6-5-9: PETIT LARCENY:
It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to commit or attempt to
commit petit larceny as defined by title 18 chapter 46, Idaho Code. (1961 Code)
6-5-10: UNLAWFUL USE OF UTILITY:
Every person who with intent to injure or defraud makes any unauthorized use of
or connection to a distribution system for water, gas, electricity, television
signal, telephone or telegram within the city shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(1961 Code)
6-5-11: FALSE PRETENSES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to obtain any food, drink, goods, wares or
merchandise under false pretenses, or who shall enter any public place and call
for refreshments, food or other articles or things and receive the same and
refuse to pay for same, or depart without paying for same or satisfying the
person from whom he received the food, refreshments, goods, wares or
merchandise within the city. (1961 Code)
6-5-12: VAGRANCY:
(Rep. by Ord. 431, 3-12-1997)
6-5-13: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or allow or permit or participate
in any drunkenness, quarreling, fighting, unlawful games or riotous or
disorderly conduct within the city. (1961 Code)
6-5-14: PROSTITUTION:
An person who pursues or advertises her vocation as a prostitute, and every
person who advertises the vocation of a prostitute or solicits for a
prostitute, and every person guilty of prostitution all within the city upon
conviction, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (1961 Code)
6-5-15: HOUSE OF PROSTITUTION:
Every person who keeps or assists in the keeping of a house of ill fame or
prostitution, or who knowingly resides therein or who knowingly rents, leases
or permits any person to occupy any house or room owned, leased or controlled
by him, to be used for this purpose within the city, shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor. (1961 Code)
6-5-16: AID TO AN OFFENSE:
Any person who shall in any way or manner, aid, abet, counsel, advise or
encourage any person in the commission of any offense mentioned in this
chapter, or in any manner encourage the commission of such offense, is hereby
declared to be a principal in the offense committed and is punishable as such.
(1961 Code)
6-5-17: BARBED WIRE AND ELECTRIC FENCES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain within the limits of
the city, any electric fence or any fence constructed in whole or in part of
barbwire, or to use barbwire as a guard to any parking or parcel of land. (1961
Code)
6-5-18: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to torture or cruelly beat, starve, or
otherwise ill treat any pet or other domestic animal in his care or charge,
whether belonging to himself or any other person within the city. (Ord. 428, 3-
12-1997)
6-5-19: DISTRIBUTION OF OBSCENE LITERATURE:
(Rep. by Ord. 431, 3-12-1997)
6-5-20: SALE OF CIGARETTES OR TOBACCO TO MINORS:
It shall be unlawful within the city for any person to sell or give away,
directly or indirectly, to any minor, any cigarettes or tobacco or any
compounds of tobacco used in filling up or making up of a cigarette. (1961
Code)
6-5-21: EXPECTORATING ON SIDEWALKS OR IN PUBLIC BUILDINGS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to expectorate or spit upon any of the
sidewalks or upon the floor of any theater, public building, church, or room
used for public assemblies within the city. (1961 Code)
6-5-22: MINORS IN POOL HALLS:
(Rep. by Ord. 431, 3-12-1997)
6-5-23: WATER FLOWING UPON STREETS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to suffer or allow any water used by them
for irrigation or any other purpose or to cause any water to flow into or upon
any public thoroughfare of the city. (1961 Code)
6-5-24: DEPOSITS OF INJURIOUS MATERIAL ON THOROUGHFARES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, place or allow to remain in, or
upon any public thoroughfare of the city any material or substance injurious to
person or property unless in the performance of authorized duties. (1961 Code)
6-5-25: LUG WHEELS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit tractors with wheels injurious to
pavement to operate upon the public thoroughfares of the city unless the
operator of such vehicles shall first plank such streets. (1961 Code)
6-5-26: KEEPING OF JUNK PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person or any secondhand dealer to store or keep
any old articles or materials which may be classed as junk, adjacent to or in
close proximity to any schoolhouse, church, public park, public grounds,
business buildings or residence within the city, without first providing proper
and tight buildings for the storage of the same, if compliance is not made it
is then hereby declared to be a nuisance. (1961 Code)
6-5-27: LOUDSPEAKERS:
It shall be unlawful to use within the city loudspeakers or amplified sound of
any kind such as may disturb the peace except as when specifically authorized
to do so by the chief of police. (1961 Code)
6-5-28: MINORS; LIQUOR OFFENSES:
No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall enter, remain in or
loiter in or about any place licensed for the sale of liquor by the drink at
retail, or for the sale of beer for consumption on the premises, except as set
forth in Idaho Code sections 23-949 and 23-1013.
Any person under the age of twenty one (21) years who shall purchase, or
attempt to purchase, possess or consume alcoholic liquor shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor.
Any person under the age of twenty one (21) years who shall purchase, attempt
to purchase, possess or consume beer shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, except
as set forth in Idaho Code section 23-1023.
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, serve or dispense beer to or by
any person under twenty one (21) years of age or to sell, serve or dispense
alcoholic liquor to or by any person under twenty one (21) years of age, proof
of which for every resident of this State shall be a valid driver's license or
an identification card issued by the State of Idaho, Department of Law
Enforcement. (Ord. 430, 3-12-1997; amd. Ord. 431, 3-12-1997)
6-5-29: MALICIOUS INJURY TO PROPERTY:
Every person who maliciously injures or destroys any real or personal property
not his own is guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 254, 1-19-1971; amd. Ord. 431, 3-
12-1997)
6-5-30: NOISE:
It is unlawful for any person to engage in acts of building construction, site
development, use of heavy equipment for earthmoving or installation of public
works, or other construction activities which involve use of concussion,
compression, power tools, or which produce bothersome illumination, noise,
dust, or similar undesirable environmental effects onto adjoining residential
properties, between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. on one day and seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M. on the succeeding day of the week.
Decibel readings, measured at the complainant's property line, shall be no
greater than fifty five (55) dB during the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M., and no greater than forty five (45) dB during the
hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M., regardless of
the source of the sound, to include but not be limited to, other equipment,
vehicles, music, etc. Every person who violates this section shall be guilty of
an infraction on the first offense and may be punished as provided in title 1,
chapter 15 of this Code, and each subsequent violation within one hundred
eighty (180) days shall be a misdemeanor. (Ord. 601, 12-12-2018)
6-5-31: CAMPING ON PUBLIC PROPERTY:
   A.   Definitions.
 
           a.   Setting up or remaining on a site for the purpose of establishing or
           maintaining a temporary or permanent place of dwelling, lodging, residence, or
           living accommodation, or otherwise being in or adjacent to a tent or sleeping
CAMPING:   bag, or atop and/or covered by materials such as bedroll, blanket, cardboard,
           newspaper, or the like, or inside some temporary shelter.
           b.   Utilizing a tent or other temporary structure for the storage of personal
           belongings.
TEMPORARY  Recreational vehicle, camper, tent, tarp, trailer, lean-to, vehicle, or other
STRUCTURE: non-permanent assembly.
 
   B.   Uses Restricted.
      1.   No person shall, as above described, camp, reside or occupy, in any
manner or fashion, whether within a closed vehicle, van, camper, trailer or
within a tent or other temporary movable structure or other contrivance, on any
city street or public property within the City of Kellogg.
      2.   Reserved for additional restrictions.
   C.   Exceptions.
      1.   Persons receiving an Event or Activity Request, Facilities
Reservation, or other permits that allow camping on public property from the
City of Kellogg Clerk's Office.
      2.   Uses commonly accepted to be associated with the use of a public
park on a temporary basis, during normal hours of operations, in conjunction
with the recreational use of such park or pavilion.
   D.   Fines and Penalties.
      1.   A first violation of this section is an infraction punishable by a
fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). A second or subsequent violation shall
be a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of no less than one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) for any one offense, or by imprisonment in the county jail not
exceeding six (6) months or by both such fine and imprisonment. Every day there
is a violation shall constitute a separate violation/offense.
(Ord. 629, 9-16-2024)
CHAPTER 6
ABANDONED COOLERS AND CONTAINERS
SECTION:
6-6-1: Unlawful Act Defined
6-6-1: UNLAWFUL ACT DEFINED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to leave or permit to
remain outside of any dwelling, building or other structure, or within any
unoccupied or abandoned building, dwelling, or other structure under his or its
control, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or
discarded icebox, refrigerator or other container which has a door or lid,
snaplock or other locking device which may not be released from the inside,
without first removing said door or lid, snaplock or other locking device or by
first fastening, bolting or locking the same in such a manner that it is
impossible to open the same by the use of the hands. (1961 Code)
CHAPTER 7
NUISANCES
SECTION:
6-7-1: Nuisances Defined
6-7-2: Rubbish On Streets, Alleys Or Sidewalks
6-7-3: Obstructions On City Sidewalks
6-7-4: Offensive Matter
6-7-1: NUISANCES DEFINED:
Anything which is injurious to health or which is indecent, or an obstruction
to the free use of property, or unlawfully obstructs free passage or use in the
customary manner of any street, alley or sidewalk or public park, or injures
any street or alley, or disturbs the peace and quiet within the city is hereby
declared to be a nuisance. (1961 Code)
6-7-2: RUBBISH ON STREETS, ALLEYS OR SIDEWALKS:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall wilfully or negligently throw, dump,
store or deposit upon any sidewalk, street, alley, or public place, or any
portion thereof, within the city any glass, nails, tacks, hoops, cans, barbed
wire, boards, or any other substance or material which would be likely to
injure any animals, vehicle or person traveling thereon, or which obstructs or
impedes the free passage of pedestrians or public travel upon such sidewalk,
street, alley, or public place, or any portion thereof, shall be deemed in
violation of this chapter. (1961 Code)
6-7-3: OBSTRUCTIONS ON CITY SIDEWALKS:
It shall be a misdemeanor for any person, firm or corporation to place any
display signs, merchandise, or other obstructions in such a manner that
restricts the unobstructed portion of any city sidewalk to less than five feet
(5') in width. (Ord. 439, 4-14-1999)
6-7-4: OFFENSIVE MATTER:
It shall be unlawful within the city, for any person, firm or corporation to
place upon any property, or to allow to remain upon any property within his or
its control any matter which is injurious to health. (1961 Code)
CHAPTER 8
PARADES
SECTION:
6-8-1: Permit Required
6-8-2: Time And Route
6-8-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
Before a parade of any nature is conducted upon the streets of the city a
permit shall be obtained from the city clerk, for which no fee is charged.
(1961 Code)
6-8-2: TIME AND ROUTE:
In order that authorities of the city may take proper steps for the protection
of participants in a parade and to properly control traffic a representative of
the group or organization planning on holding a parade shall at the time of
application for a permit for same give the city clerk information as to the
date of the parade, time of day, nature of the parade and the route planned.
(1961 Code)
TITLE 7
FIRE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
FIRE DISTRICT
SECTION:
7-1-1: Fire Limits Designated
7-1-2: Restrictions Governed By Building Code As Adopted
7-1-1: FIRE LIMITS DESIGNATED:
All those portions of the city of Kellogg, Idaho, commonly known and designated
as follows:
East One-Half (E 1/2) of Block Twenty-two (22), West One-half (W 1/2) of Block

Blocks Twenty-eight (28), and Thirty-five (35) of the City; all of Blocks One
(1), Two (2), Three (3), Four (4), Five (5), and Six (6) of Sinclair's Addition
